title: About

Raymond Liu Ao
Originally from Lima, Peru, I am a Philosophy, Politics, and Economics (PPE) student at the University of Pennsylvania. Interested in exploring the uses and implications of AI in daily life, this blog discusses how LLM can help us (or not) in commonly encountered scenarios.

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
text:
I‚Äôm reading Reid Hoffman and Greg Beato‚Äôs Superagency: What Could Possibly Go Right with Our AI Future‚Äîa book that argues for optimism about generative AI and its potential to enhance human agency. As someone who identifies as a gloomer about AI, I‚Äôm approaching this with skepticism but genuine curiosity.
This is part 1 of 5 reviews covering the entire book. Pages 1-47: The introduction and framing.

Superagency by Reid Hoffman and Greg Beato

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
text:
I‚Äôm reading Reid Hoffman and Greg Beato‚Äôs Superagency: What Could Possibly Go Right with Our AI Future‚Äîa book that argues for optimism about generative AI and its potential to enhance human agency. As someone who identifies as a gloomer about AI, I‚Äôm approaching this with skepticism but genuine curiosity.
This is part 1 of 5 reviews covering the entire book. Pages 1-47: The introduction and framing.

Superagency by Reid Hoffman and Greg Beato

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
section: The Historical Framing: Art, Luddites, and Printing Presses
text:
The Historical Framing: Art, Luddites, and Printing Presses
The introduction opens with an interesting historical analogy. Hoffman and Beato walk through past technological disruptions:
Socrates and Art: Socrates opposed art because it failed to capture the conversational, evolutionary, iterative process of discussion-based learning. Written text was static; dialogue was dynamic.
The Luddites: Workers who resisted industrial machinery that threatened their livelihoods and ways of life.
The Printing Press: A technology that faced backlash from those who feared the democratization of knowledge.
The pattern is clear: history is full of examples of technological backlash. The book frames AI as the latest in this line‚Äîanother ‚Äúinfrastructural change event‚Äù that will transform human capacity and agency.
I‚Äôll admit, the framing is effective. The core question the book poses is compelling: ‚ÄúCan we continue to maintain control of our lives, and successfully plot our own destinies?‚Äù in the age of AI.

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
section: History Is Written by the Winners
text:
History Is Written by the Winners
Here‚Äôs where my skepticism kicks in.
Yes, all these technological disruptions‚Äîart, steam power, the printing press‚Äîwere consequential and enabled human agency in important ways:
Art captured feelings, periods, and provided first-hand historical resources.
Steam power and the Industrial Revolution brought unimaginable productivity and capital accumulation, leading to the consolidation of modern cities.
The printing press enabled communication and knowledge dissemination like never before.
We‚Äôve all benefited from these major strides, one way or another. But the more closely we examine the nuances of these pivotal moments, the more we realize there‚Äôs much more to the story.
The problem is that we often focus on the positives‚Äîmaybe as a sign of human delusion, or a craving to minimize problems. Important details get left behind. History is written by the winners, after all.

The Industrial Revolution: productivity gains alongside worker displacement

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
section: What the Winners‚Äô History Leaves Out
text:
What the Winners‚Äô History Leaves Out

The Industrial Revolution‚Äôs Dark Side
The steam engine and industrialization brought unprecedented productivity. But they also brought: - Brutal working conditions in factories - Child labor - Destruction of artisan crafts and traditional ways of life - Environmental degradation that we‚Äôre still dealing with - Massive wealth inequality and the creation of exploitative labor systems
According to historical analysis of the Industrial Revolution, while productivity soared, real wages for workers stagnated or declined for decades. The ‚Äúwinners‚Äù who wrote that history were the factory owners and industrialists, not the displaced weavers or child laborers.


The Printing Press and Information Chaos
The printing press democratized knowledge‚Äîbut it also: - Enabled mass propaganda - Facilitated religious wars and sectarian violence - Created information overload that people weren‚Äôt equipped to handle - Disrupted existing knowledge gatekeepers (sometimes for good, sometimes not)
The Reformation, enabled by printing technology, led to centuries of religious conflict. That‚Äôs not in the optimistic framing.


The Luddites Were Right About Some Things
We use ‚ÄúLuddite‚Äù as an insult for technophobes. But the original Luddites weren‚Äôt irrationally afraid of technology‚Äîthey were skilled workers watching their livelihoods and communities be destroyed by machines that enriched factory owners.
Their concerns about who benefits from technological change were valid. The technology did increase productivity, but the gains went to capital owners, not workers. The Luddites lost that fight, so history remembers them as backwards resistors rather than people with legitimate concerns about economic justice.

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
text:
The Agency Question: For Whom?
Hoffman and Beato frame AI as an ‚Äúagency enabler‚Äù‚Äîtechnology that will enhance our capacity to ‚Äúdo what we ought to do‚Äù and ‚Äúplot our own destinies.‚Äù
But here‚Äôs the critical question the introduction doesn‚Äôt adequately address: Whose agency gets enabled?

Technology Doesn‚Äôt Distribute Benefits Evenly
Past technological revolutions increased aggregate human capacity and agency. But the distribution was wildly unequal: - Factory owners gained agency; workers often lost autonomy - Landowners who adopted new agricultural tech thrived; tenant farmers were displaced - Early adopters of communication technology gained power; those without access fell further behind
When Hoffman talks about AI enabling ‚Äúour‚Äù agency, who is ‚Äúwe‚Äù? Tech founders and investors? Knowledge workers with access to cutting-edge tools? Or also the truck drivers, customer service workers, and radiologists whose jobs might be automated?


Have We Forgotten Our Ways of Life?
Each technological revolution didn‚Äôt just change what people could do‚Äîit changed how people lived. Industrialization pulled people from rural communities into urban factories. The printing press disrupted oral traditions and face-to-face knowledge transmission.
Some of these changes were positive. Some represented the loss of valuable ways of life that we can never recover.
The introduction‚Äôs optimistic framing acknowledges these past disruptions but seems confident that AI will be different‚Äîthat we can get the benefits without the costs. History suggests otherwise.

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
section: What I‚Äôm Looking For in the Rest of the Book
text:
What I‚Äôm Looking For in the Rest of the Book
The introduction sets up an optimistic case for AI as an agency enabler, using historical technological disruptions as precedent. The framing is well-done and intellectually honest about past backlash to new technologies.
But it seems to brush past the real costs of those past revolutions. The ‚Äúwinners‚Äù narrative focuses on aggregate gains while downplaying distributional concerns and the destruction of existing ways of life.
As I continue reading, I‚Äôm looking for:
Distributional analysis: Who specifically gains agency from AI, and who loses it?
Cost acknowledgment: What ways of life, skills, or social structures might we lose, and are those losses acceptable?
Power dynamics: How do we ensure AI benefits are distributed more equitably than past technological revolutions?
Concrete mechanisms: Not just ‚ÄúAI will enable agency,‚Äù but how and for whom specifically?
The book asks: ‚ÄúWhat could possibly go right with our AI future?‚Äù But the introduction‚Äôs own historical examples suggest we should also ask: ‚ÄúWhat will go wrong, and for whom?‚Äù
History is written by the winners. I‚Äôm reading this book to see if Hoffman and Beato can imagine an AI future where there are fewer losers than in past technological revolutions‚Äîor if they‚Äôre just writing the winners‚Äô narrative before the story has finished.

title: Superagency Review #1: History Is Written by the Winners
text:
Up Next
Review #2 will cover pages 48-94, where I expect the book to start making its positive case for AI more explicitly. I‚Äôll be watching to see if it addresses the distributional concerns raised by its own historical framing.
Stay tuned.

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
text:
I have an upcoming interview for a Santander CIB Investment Banking Analyst Program, specifically for their DCM (Debt Capital Markets) division. This is different from the consulting interviews I‚Äôve been preparing for‚Äîfinance interviews require understanding specific firms, technical knowledge about debt markets, and different types of behavioral questions.
Since I‚Äôve been using AI for consulting prep, I decided to test whether Claude and Perplexity could help me pivot to finance interview preparation.

Claude conducting research on Santander‚Äôs DCM business and interview approach

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
text:
I have an upcoming interview for a Santander CIB Investment Banking Analyst Program, specifically for their DCM (Debt Capital Markets) division. This is different from the consulting interviews I‚Äôve been preparing for‚Äîfinance interviews require understanding specific firms, technical knowledge about debt markets, and different types of behavioral questions.
Since I‚Äôve been using AI for consulting prep, I decided to test whether Claude and Perplexity could help me pivot to finance interview preparation.

Claude conducting research on Santander‚Äôs DCM business and interview approach

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
text:
The Prompts I Used

Initial Research Request to Claude
My first prompt:

‚ÄúFirst and foremost, I am more so interested in understanding DCM, and potential BEHAVIORAL questions that might arise.
Why DCM? Why DCM LatAm? Why Santander DCM?
Use the web to thoroughly search and understand more about the firm, how the firm talks about itself, and what common behavioral questions do they engage with for their IB process.‚Äù

Claude responded:

‚ÄúI‚Äôll conduct thorough research on Santander CIB, their DCM business, and their interview process. Let me search for information about how they present themselves, their Latin America focus, and common interview questions.‚Äù

It then ran searches for: - ‚ÄúSantander Corporate Investment Banking DCM‚Äù (10 results) - Started searching the web for additional information


Perplexity Deep Dive
I also used Perplexity‚Äôs research feature with multiple targeted searches:

‚ÄúSantander CIB debt capital markets‚Äù
‚ÄúSantander investment banking culture values‚Äù
‚ÄúSantander CIB Latin America strategy‚Äù

Perplexity Research tool found 128 sources including: - Debt Capital Markets | Santander Corporate & Investment Banking - From personalization to social values: what is shaking up investment [banking] - Macro & Strategy Research - The past, present and future of debt capital markets - [PDF] Culture Report 2019 - Banco Santander - Santander US Capital Markets

Perplexity gathering and reviewing sources on Santander DCM

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
text:
What Actually Helped

Firm-Specific Research
Both tools pulled relevant information about Santander‚Äôs positioning: - Their focus on Latin America markets and how that differentiates them - Recent deals and market activity in DCM - Corporate values and culture statements - Strategic priorities in debt capital markets
This gave me talking points for ‚ÄúWhy Santander‚Äù that were specific rather than generic.


Understanding DCM vs.¬†Other IB Divisions
The AI helped clarify: - What DCM analysts actually do day-to-day - How DCM differs from M&A or equity capital markets - Why someone might choose DCM over other finance paths - Technical concepts I needed to understand (bond pricing, credit ratings, syndication)


Behavioral Question Preparation
The tools suggested finance-specific behavioral questions that differ from consulting: - ‚ÄúWalk me through a DCF‚Äù (technical behavioral) - ‚ÄúWhy debt capital markets vs.¬†other finance roles?‚Äù - ‚ÄúHow do you handle working with difficult clients on tight deadlines?‚Äù - ‚ÄúTell me about a time you analyzed complex financial information‚Äù
These are different from consulting‚Äôs case-focused approach.


Identifying Knowledge Gaps
The research helped me realize what I didn‚Äôt know: - Specific debt instruments Santander specializes in - Recent Latin American market trends affecting DCM - Technical terminology I needed to learn - The difference between investment-grade and high-yield debt origination

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
text:
Significant Limitations

Surface-Level Firm Knowledge
The biggest problem: AI gives you the information that‚Äôs publicly available on corporate websites and general industry sources. It can‚Äôt tell you: - What Santander‚Äôs DCM team culture is actually like - Specific deals they‚Äôre working on that aren‚Äôt public - Internal priorities that aren‚Äôt in press releases - What actually impresses their interviewers vs.¬†what sounds good on paper
According to Wall Street Oasis research on IB recruiting, the candidates who succeed show knowledge that goes beyond what AI can find‚Äîinsider perspectives from networking, recent deal gossip, and understanding of team dynamics.


Generic Behavioral Answers
When I asked Claude to help refine my answers to ‚ÄúWhy DCM?‚Äù, it produced polished but generic responses: - ‚ÄúI‚Äôm drawn to the analytical rigor of debt markets‚Ä¶‚Äù - ‚ÄúThe complexity of structuring transactions appeals to me‚Ä¶‚Äù - ‚ÄúI want to work at the intersection of capital markets and corporate strategy‚Ä¶‚Äù
These sound like everyone else‚Äôs AI-polished answers. The interviewers at Santander have probably heard variations of these from dozens of candidates using similar tools.


Can‚Äôt Teach Technical Skills
AI can explain what a DCF is, but it can‚Äôt help you build the muscle memory of actually modeling one under time pressure. It can‚Äôt simulate the experience of being asked to walk through a valuation on a whiteboard while someone watches.
Finance interview prep resources emphasize that technical skills require hands-on practice with actual models, not just conceptual understanding.


Outdated Information
Some of the sources Perplexity pulled were from 2019 (the Culture Report). The finance industry moves quickly‚Äîstrategies, priorities, and team structures change. Relying on AI-found sources without verifying recency is risky.


Misses Networking Insights
The most valuable interview prep for finance comes from talking to people who work at the firm or in similar roles. AI can‚Äôt replace: - Coffee chats with current Santander analysts - Alumni connections who know the interview process - Understanding what specific interviewers care about - Getting feedback on your story from people in the industry

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
section: Consulting Prep vs.¬†Finance Prep with AI
text:
Consulting Prep vs.¬†Finance Prep with AI

What Transfers
Some aspects of using AI for consulting prep apply to finance: - Organizing practice materials and tracking progress - Getting quick explanations of concepts - Structuring answers using frameworks - Identifying areas where you need more preparation


What‚Äôs Different
Finance interviews require different AI usage:
Technical Knowledge: Consulting is more about frameworks and problem-solving approach. Finance requires specific technical knowledge (financial modeling, valuation methods, market mechanics) that you need to practice hands-on.
Firm Research: Consulting firms are more about ‚Äúfit‚Äù and problem-solving ability. Finance firms want to know you understand their specific business lines, recent deals, and market positioning.
Answer Style: Consulting wants structured, MECE thinking demonstrated verbally. Finance wants technical competence demonstrated through modeling and concise, confident answers about markets.
Preparation Balance: For consulting, AI can handle maybe 40% of prep (frameworks, structure, case types). For finance, it‚Äôs more like 20%, you need more hands-on technical practice and human networking.

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
text:
My Actual Approach

Using AI for Initial Research Phase
I‚Äôm using Claude and Perplexity to: - Get baseline understanding of Santander‚Äôs DCM business - Compile a list of recent deals and market trends - Understand basic DCM technical concepts - Draft initial answers to behavioral questions
But I treat this as the starting point, not the final product.


Following Up with Human Sources
After AI research, I‚Äôm: - Reaching out to Santander employees on LinkedIn - Talking to friends in investment banking about DCM - Getting my behavioral answers reviewed by people in finance - Asking specific questions about Santander‚Äôs Latin America focus


Technical Skill Building
For the technical components, AI isn‚Äôt much help. I‚Äôm: - Working through actual DCF models - Practicing explaining valuation methods out loud - Reviewing recent debt deals and their structures - Doing mock technical questions with finance friends


Verifying Everything
Any specific fact or claim from AI research, I verify: - Check Santander‚Äôs official investor relations materials - Look up recent news about their DCM business - Confirm market trends with multiple sources - Cross-reference technical concepts with textbooks
The AI can point me toward information, but I don‚Äôt trust it without verification.

title: Switching from Consulting to Finance Prep with AI
text:
Final Assessment
Using AI to pivot from consulting to finance interview prep is helpful but limited. It‚Äôs good for: - Quick baseline research on the firm and role - Understanding how finance interviews differ from consulting - Getting initial structure for behavioral answers - Identifying what you don‚Äôt know
But it‚Äôs insufficient for: - Developing real technical skills - Understanding firm-specific culture and priorities - Creating distinctive, memorable answers - Getting the insider knowledge that networking provides
Finance interviews, even more than consulting, require human connections and hands-on technical practice. AI can accelerate the research phase, but it can‚Äôt replace the core preparation activities that actually matter.
The risk is thinking that comprehensive AI research is enough. It‚Äôs not. The candidates who get offers at places like Santander DCM are the ones who combine efficient research with deep technical preparation and strong industry networks‚Äîthings AI can‚Äôt provide.

title: Experimenting with Vibe Creation Using LLMs
text:
I‚Äôve been experimenting with what I‚Äôm calling ‚Äúvibe creation‚Äù in Claude‚Äîessentially asking the LLM to generate or interpret atmospheric descriptions for different contexts. The goal was to see how well these models understand and reproduce subjective, mood-based content rather than factual information.
 Testing different prompts to generate atmospheric descriptions

title: Experimenting with Vibe Creation Using LLMs
text:
I‚Äôve been experimenting with what I‚Äôm calling ‚Äúvibe creation‚Äù in Claude‚Äîessentially asking the LLM to generate or interpret atmospheric descriptions for different contexts. The goal was to see how well these models understand and reproduce subjective, mood-based content rather than factual information.
 Testing different prompts to generate atmospheric descriptions

title: Experimenting with Vibe Creation Using LLMs
text:
The Prompts I Tested

Starting Simple
My first prompt was straightforward:

‚ÄúDescribe the vibe of a rainy coffee shop at 3pm on a Tuesday‚Äù

Claude generated a description that hit the expected notes‚Äîmuted conversations, steam from coffee cups, the rhythmic sound of rain. It was accurate but generic, the kind of description you‚Äôd find in any piece of atmospheric writing.


Adding Specificity
I tried making the prompt more specific:

‚ÄúDescribe the vibe of a college library during finals week at 2am. Include sounds, lighting, and the feeling of collective stress‚Äù

This produced better results. The model captured details like the fluorescent lighting, the sound of highlighters on paper, and the ‚Äúquiet panic‚Äù of students. It understood the assignment but still felt somewhat detached‚Äîlike someone describing a scene they‚Äôd read about rather than experienced.


Testing Negative Space
Here‚Äôs where it got interesting. I asked:

‚ÄúDescribe the vibe of an empty office building at night. Focus on what‚Äôs NOT there rather than what is‚Äù

Claude struggled more with this. It could describe absence‚Äîno people, no noise‚Äîbut couldn‚Äôt quite capture the uncanny feeling of a space designed for activity sitting dormant. The descriptions remained surface-level. The output focused on the lack of meetings, chatter, talk, noise in the office. But it did not capture the liminal-space-like, vast, expansive (almost scary) vibe of an empty office in the way the show Severance, for instance, can.
 Comparing outputs from different prompting approaches

title: Experimenting with Vibe Creation Using LLMs
text:
What Worked and What Didn‚Äôt

Strengths
The LLM is good at: - Assembling sensory details that conventionally fit a scene - Understanding cultural contexts (‚Äúfinals week‚Äù immediately triggered appropriate stress markers) - Maintaining consistency within a single atmospheric description - Responding to structural prompts (‚Äúfocus on sounds‚Äù vs ‚Äúfocus on lighting‚Äù)


Limitations
Where it falls short: - Generating truly novel atmospheric combinations - Capturing subtle emotional undertones that aren‚Äôt explicitly named - Moving beyond stereotypical associations (coffee shop = cozy, library = studious) - Understanding the relationship between physical space and psychological state in non-obvious ways
The model seems to work from a database of common associations rather than synthesizing new atmospheric understanding.

title: Experimenting with Vibe Creation Using LLMs
section: Why This Matters (From a Skeptical Angle)
text:
Why This Matters (From a Skeptical Angle)

The Homogenization Problem
If everyone starts using LLMs to generate atmospheric descriptions for creative projects, writing, or marketing, we risk creating a feedback loop of averaged-out vibes. The model can only reproduce what it‚Äôs seen in training data, which means we get the most statistically likely description of any given mood or setting.
After all, LLMs tend to regress toward mean responses when generating creative content, potentially flattening the diversity of human expression.


Lost Nuance
Real atmospheric writing comes from personal observation and specific experience. When I asked Claude to describe my college library during finals, it gave me a generic college library experience. It couldn‚Äôt know about the specific smell of old heating systems mixed with energy drinks, or the way light reflects off that one weird pillar in the corner.


Useful But Limited Tool
This isn‚Äôt to say vibe creation with LLMs is useless. It‚Äôs good for: - Quick brainstorming when you‚Äôre stuck - Getting a baseline description to then personalize - Understanding how certain settings are conventionally described
But treating it as a replacement for actual observation and personal experience would result in flatter, less distinctive creative work.

title: Experimenting with Vibe Creation Using LLMs
text:
Final Thoughts
Playing with vibe creation revealed both the capabilities and constraints of current LLMs. They‚Äôre sophisticated pattern-matching systems that can assemble convincing atmospheric descriptions from training data, but they lack the experiential knowledge that makes truly evocative writing memorable.
The exercise reinforced my skepticism about over-relying on these tools for creative work. They‚Äôre useful for scaffolding and inspiration, but the most interesting atmospheric details still need to come from human observation and experience.
For anyone trying similar experiments: push the model toward specificity and unconventional combinations. The more generic your prompt, the more generic your output.

title: AI Email Management That Actually Works
text:
I set up SaneBox to manage my email and it‚Äôs been running for about a week now. Instead of manually sorting through everything, the AI decides what‚Äôs important and what can wait.
 AI automatically categorizing emails by priority level

title: AI Email Management That Actually Works
text:
I set up SaneBox to manage my email and it‚Äôs been running for about a week now. Instead of manually sorting through everything, the AI decides what‚Äôs important and what can wait.
 AI automatically categorizing emails by priority level

title: AI Email Management That Actually Works
text:
How It Sorts Things Out

Priority Filtering
SaneBox learns from which emails I actually open and respond to. Work emails from my team get flagged as important, while newsletters and promotional stuff gets moved to a separate folder. It‚Äôs not perfect but catches most of the obvious stuff.


Smart Scheduling
Gmail‚Äôs AI also suggests response times and can schedule emails to send later. I‚Äôve been using it to send emails during business hours even when I‚Äôm working late, so I don‚Äôt look like I‚Äôm always online.


Quick Replies
The suggested responses are actually useful for simple emails. When someone sends a meeting request, it‚Äôll suggest ‚ÄúLooks good‚Äù or ‚ÄúLet me check my calendar‚Äù which saves typing the same responses over and over.
 AI-generated reply suggestions for common email types

title: AI Email Management That Actually Works
text:
What I‚Äôve Noticed

Less Time Sorting
The main benefit is spending less time deciding what to read first. Important emails show up in the main inbox, everything else gets organized automatically.


Fewer Missed Messages
Before, urgent emails would get buried under promotional stuff. Now they‚Äôre separated, so I‚Äôm less likely to miss something important.


Still Need to Check
The AI sometimes gets it wrong - puts important emails in the low-priority folder or flags spam as urgent. You still need to glance through everything, but it‚Äôs more organized.
It‚Äôs a decent time-saver for people who get a lot of email. Not life-changing, but removes some of the daily friction of inbox management. The filtering works better than I expected, though you need to train it for a few days before it gets your priorities right.

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
AI tools like ChatGPT and Claude can handle routine tasks that usually take significant time. Here are five practical applications that work reliably.
 Common tasks where AI provides immediate value

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
AI tools like ChatGPT and Claude can handle routine tasks that usually take significant time. Here are five practical applications that work reliably.
 Common tasks where AI provides immediate value

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
1. Meal Planning and Recipes
Turn ingredients into meal plans instantly.
Basic ingredient prompt:
I have chicken breast, rice, and broccoli. 
Give me 3 different 30-minute meals with instructions.
Weekly planning prompt:
Create a 5-day meal plan for 2 people, $60 budget. 
Include grocery list organized by store section.
 AI generates recipes based on available ingredients and dietary preferences
AI handles dietary restrictions, cooking time constraints, and budget limitations effectively. The grocery lists are particularly useful since they organize items by store layout.

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
2. Email and Message Writing
Improve clarity and tone in professional communication.
Email revision prompt:
Make this email more professional and concise:
[paste your draft]
Difficult conversation prompt:
Help me write a polite but firm email declining this request:
[explain situation]
Meeting follow-up prompt:
Draft a follow-up email summarizing these meeting points:
[list key decisions and action items]
This works for text messages, LinkedIn messages, and any written communication where tone matters.

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
3. Quick Learning and Research
Get structured explanations on unfamiliar topics.
Concept explanation prompt:
Explain [topic] in simple terms, then give me 
5 follow-up questions to test my understanding.
Skill learning prompt:
I need to learn Excel pivot tables for work. 
Give me a step-by-step tutorial focusing on the most practical features.
Research synthesis prompt:
Compare the top 3 options for [product/service] 
with pros and cons for each.
 AI breaks down complex topics into manageable learning steps
AI excels at creating structured learning paths and synthesizing information from multiple angles.

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
4. Travel and Event Planning
Generate detailed itineraries and logistics.
Trip planning prompt:
Plan a 3-day weekend trip to [destination] for [number] people 
with a $[amount] budget. Include transportation, accommodation, 
and daily activities.
Local exploration prompt:
What are 5 lesser-known attractions in [city] 
that locals recommend?
Event planning prompt:
Create a timeline and checklist for planning a 
[birthday party/dinner party/work event] for [number] people.
AI handles multiple constraints simultaneously - budget, time, preferences, and logistics.

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
5. Home Management and Finances
Get practical advice for household and money management.
Home maintenance prompt:
My [appliance/fixture] is [problem description]. 
Walk me through troubleshooting steps from simple to complex.
Budget planning prompt:
I make $[amount] monthly, fixed expenses are $[amount]. 
Create a realistic budget with savings and discretionary spending.
Purchase decision prompt:
I'm considering buying [item] for [purpose]. 
What factors should I evaluate? Create a decision framework.
 AI provides structured approaches to financial and household decisions
These applications work because AI can process multiple variables and provide step-by-step guidance for complex decisions.

title: 5 Ways to Use AI Every Day
text:
Implementation Notes
Prompt specificity matters. Include relevant details like budget, timeframe, number of people, and specific constraints.
Follow-up questions improve results. Ask for alternatives, simplifications, or additional detail as needed.
Save effective prompts. Keep a note file with prompts that work well for repeated use.
These five applications cover the most common daily planning and decision-making tasks. Each provides immediate time savings and often produces better results than manual research.

title: AI-Assisted Grocery Shopping and Meal Prep
text:
I tried out the AnyList grocery app today and it‚Äôs different from just writing things down on paper. Instead of my usual scattered notes and forgotten items, the app organizes everything and suggests what I might need.
 AI-generated grocery list organized by store layout

title: AI-Assisted Grocery Shopping and Meal Prep
text:
I tried out the AnyList grocery app today and it‚Äôs different from just writing things down on paper. Instead of my usual scattered notes and forgotten items, the app organizes everything and suggests what I might need.
 AI-generated grocery list organized by store layout

title: AI-Assisted Grocery Shopping and Meal Prep
text:
What It Actually Does

Tracks What You Need
The app learns from your purchase history and can predict when you‚Äôre running low on regular items. It suggested I needed milk and bread this week before I even thought about it. Not perfect, but surprisingly accurate for staples I buy regularly.


Organizes by Store Layout
Instead of jumping around the store, the list is organized by sections - produce, dairy, meat, etc. Some apps even know the specific layout of stores you frequent, so your list follows the actual aisles.


Meal Planning Integration
You can add meals for the week and it automatically generates ingredient lists. When I planned tacos for Tuesday, it added ground beef, tortillas, and lettuce to my list. It also checked what I already had at home based on recent purchases.

title: AI-Assisted Grocery Shopping and Meal Prep
text:
Practical Benefits

Less Time in Store
Following an organized list means less wandering around looking for items. I‚Äôve noticed my shopping trips are about 15-20 minutes shorter.


Fewer Forgotten Items
The app remembers things I consistently buy but often forget to write down, like batteries or cleaning supplies.


Better Meal Planning
When you can see ingredient costs upfront, it‚Äôs easier to plan meals within budget. The app sometimes suggests cheaper alternatives for expensive items.


Automatic Coupons
Many apps integrate with store loyalty programs and apply relevant coupons automatically. I‚Äôve saved money without having to hunt for deals.

title: AI-Assisted Grocery Shopping and Meal Prep
text:
What Doesn‚Äôt Work Perfectly

Learning Period
It takes a few weeks for the app to understand your shopping patterns. Early suggestions were often wrong.


Store-Specific Features
Advanced features like aisle mapping only work with certain grocery chains. Smaller or independent stores usually don‚Äôt have this integration.


Fresh Produce Timing
The AI isn‚Äôt great at predicting when you need fresh items since it depends on how quickly you use them.
Overall, it‚Äôs a useful tool that makes grocery shopping more organized. The meal planning aspect is particularly helpful for busy weeks when you need to think ahead. Not essential, but definitely convenient once you get used to it.

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
I‚Äôm Peruvian but never learned to cook Lomo Saltado properly. Living in a college dorm with limited equipment, I decided to use Claude as a tutor to learn. But instead of just asking for help, I ran an experiment: two separate tutoring sessions using different prompting approaches to see if prompt engineering actually makes a difference for learning.

A finished plate of Lomo Saltado - the goal of the tutoring sessions

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
I‚Äôm Peruvian but never learned to cook Lomo Saltado properly. Living in a college dorm with limited equipment, I decided to use Claude as a tutor to learn. But instead of just asking for help, I ran an experiment: two separate tutoring sessions using different prompting approaches to see if prompt engineering actually makes a difference for learning.

A finished plate of Lomo Saltado - the goal of the tutoring sessions

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
The Experiment Setup

Session 1: Vanilla Claude
I started a fresh conversation with no special prompting. Just asked:

‚ÄúI want to learn how to cook Lomo Saltado in my college dorm. Can you teach me?‚Äù

Claude immediately provided a comprehensive ingredient list, equipment needs, and step-by-step instructions. Efficient and informative.


Session 2: Structured Tutoring Prompt
For the second session, I used the Mollick structured tutoring prompt, which instructs the AI to: - Introduce itself by name - Ask questions one at a time before teaching - Gather information about the student‚Äôs prior knowledge - Use leading questions rather than just providing answers - Provide emotional support and encouragement
The prompt started with:

‚ÄúYou are an upbeat, encouraging tutor who helps students understand concepts by explaining ideas and asking students questions. Start by introducing yourself to the student as their AI-Tutor who is happy to help them with any questions‚Ä¶‚Äù

Same question about learning Lomo Saltado, but this time Claude introduced itself as ‚ÄúAlex‚Äù and asked about my cooking experience before giving any instructions.

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
How The Sessions Differed

Session 1: Information First
Claude immediately delivered: - Complete ingredient list with substitutions - All equipment needed - Step-by-step cooking instructions - Do‚Äôs and don‚Äôts - Storage and freezing tips
It was like reading a very thorough cookbook. Efficient, but I started feeling overwhelmed around the ‚Äúdo‚Äôs and don‚Äôts‚Äù section because it kept adding more information without checking if I was following along.
When I asked for a ‚Äúcookbook style summary‚Äù later, it became clear I‚Äôd experienced information overload.


Session 2: Questions First
Claude asked: - What‚Äôs my cooking experience level? - What equipment do I have access to? - What do I already know about Lomo Saltado?
When I mentioned I‚Äôm Peruvian and grew up eating this dish, the whole approach changed. Claude acknowledged my cultural connection, didn‚Äôt waste time explaining what Lomo Saltado is, and focused on translating my taste memory into cooking technique.
The information came in smaller chunks, each followed by a question to check understanding. It felt more like a conversation than a lecture.

Comparing the two Claude tutoring session interfaces

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
When Things Went Wrong
I intentionally messed up the recipe in both sessions to see how each tutor would handle mistakes.

Session 1 Response
When I said I overcooked the meat, added too much soy sauce, and the tomatoes were mushy, Claude gave practical solutions: - Slice overcooked meat thinner - Balance soy sauce with vinegar and sugar - Remove mushy tomatoes and add fresh ones
Organized by problem, very solution-focused. It worked, but felt clinical.
At one point I got frustrated and said ‚ÄúI do NOT want to try again tomorrow. I want to DO IT NOW.‚Äù The tutor went into emergency rescue mode, which helped but didn‚Äôt address the emotional crisis.


Session 2 Response
When I introduced the same problems, Claude started with:

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt panic! This is totally normal when learning, and yes, we can salvage this!‚Äù

Then provided the same practical solutions, but added:

‚ÄúRemember: Even ‚Äòmistakes‚Äô can taste good, and every Peruvian abuela had to start somewhere!‚Äù

This was culturally resonant and emotionally supportive. The solutions were similar, but the tone acknowledged that learning involves struggle, not just technical problem-solving.
I didn‚Äôt have the same emotional breakdown in Session 2. The earlier relationship-building (validation, personalization) seemed to prevent it.

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
The Final Cookbook Recipes
Both sessions ended with me asking for a clean cookbook-style recipe.

Session 1 Recipe

Heavy use of emoji headers (ü•©, üçÖ, ‚è∞)
Multiple subsections: Equipment, Ingredients, Shortcuts, Steps, Money-Saving Tips, Dorm Hacks, Storage
Comprehensive resource document
Generic college student advice



Session 2 Recipe

Cleaner visual hierarchy
Sections: What You‚Äôll Need ‚Üí Game Plan ‚Üí Key Success Tips ‚Üí Storage
More scannable layout
Tailored to: college student + new cook + Peruvian heritage + meal prep constraints

Both recipes are accurate and functional. Session 1 is more comprehensive; Session 2 is more personalized to my specific situation.

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
What Actually Made a Difference

The Structured Prompt Won
Session 2 was the better tutoring experience because:
Better sequencing: Asking questions before teaching meant the information was calibrated to what I actually needed, not everything the AI knows about Lomo Saltado.
Personalization: Learning I was Peruvian changed how Claude explained things. It connected to my existing knowledge (‚ÄúYou know what it should taste like‚Äù) rather than starting from zero.
Emotional support: Normalizing mistakes and providing encouragement made me more likely to persist through problems. This matters for skill-building where failure is inevitable.
Active learning: Session 2 ended each explanation with a question, forcing me to think rather than passively receive information.


Where Session 1 Was Better
Speed: If you just want information fast, the vanilla approach delivers immediately without the question-gathering phase.
Comprehensiveness: The final recipe from Session 1 had more detail on meal prep, freezing, and storage tips.
No preamble: Some people find the ‚Äúgetting to know you‚Äù phase of structured tutoring annoying if they just want answers.

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
Does This Matter Beyond Cooking?

The Pedagogy Research
The structured prompt approach aligns with established learning science. According to research on effective tutoring, good tutoring involves: - Assessing prior knowledge before teaching - Providing scaffolded support - Using questions to promote active learning - Giving emotional encouragement alongside technical help
These aren‚Äôt AI-specific insights‚Äîthey‚Äôre how human tutoring works best too.


The Limitations
Even with perfect prompting, AI tutoring has constraints:
Can‚Äôt taste your food: Claude couldn‚Äôt tell me if my Lomo Saltado actually tasted right. I had to rely on my own judgment.
Can‚Äôt see your technique: When I said the meat was overcooked, Claude couldn‚Äôt see whether I was cutting it correctly or using too high heat. The advice was generic.
Can‚Äôt adapt in real-time: A human tutor watching me cook would catch mistakes as they happen. AI only responds to what I describe.
Generic cultural knowledge: Session 2‚Äôs cultural references (‚ÄúPeruvian abuela‚Äù) were sweet but generic. It didn‚Äôt know my actual family‚Äôs cooking style or regional variations.


When Structured Prompting Matters Most
The prompt engineering made the biggest difference when: - Learning something new (not just looking up facts) - Dealing with frustration or mistakes - Needing personalized guidance - Building skills through practice
For quick information retrieval, vanilla Claude is probably fine. For actual learning, structure helps.

title: Testing AI as a Tutor: Does Prompt Structure Actually Matter?
text:
What I Learned

About AI Tutoring
Prompt engineering isn‚Äôt just theoretical optimization‚Äîit genuinely changed my learning experience. The structured prompt created better dialogue, personalization, and emotional support.
But even good prompting has limits. AI tutoring works best for knowledge-based learning where you can verify results yourself. For physical skills like cooking, you still need to trust your own judgment about the outcome.


About Learning Lomo Saltado
I actually cooked it. Both sessions gave me functional recipes, but Session 2‚Äôs emotional support made me more willing to try despite knowing I‚Äôd probably mess up.
The AI was right about one thing: even mistakes taste pretty good, and you learn by doing.


About Prompt Design
Good tutoring prompts should include: - Instructions to gather context before teaching - One-question-at-a-time pacing - Emotional scaffolding for when things go wrong - Requirements to keep students actively thinking
These aren‚Äôt complex AI techniques‚Äîthey‚Äôre just principles of good teaching, codified for an AI to follow.
If you‚Äôre using AI to learn something practical, take five minutes to set up a proper tutoring prompt. The difference is real.

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
text:
For the Cuzco Crunch project, Eury and I needed to test two product concepts before committing to one. Instead of recruiting actual participants for a focus group, we decided to try something experimental: using ChatGPT to simulate a focus group with 10 diverse personas.

Cuzco Crunch: Golden plantain slices with Peruvian sal de Maras

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
text:
For the Cuzco Crunch project, Eury and I needed to test two product concepts before committing to one. Instead of recruiting actual participants for a focus group, we decided to try something experimental: using ChatGPT to simulate a focus group with 10 diverse personas.

Cuzco Crunch: Golden plantain slices with Peruvian sal de Maras

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
text:
The Experimental Design

Two Products to Test
Cuzco Crunch (Product A): Positioned as premium - golden, ultra-crispy plantain slices with Peruvian sal de Maras for a mineral-salt finish. Natural sweetness from plantain, meant to be versatile. Price: $7 for 1.5 oz.
Plantain Lite (Product B): Positioned as everyday - lighter snack with delicate crunch and simple seasoning. Emphasizes convenience and portability. Price: $5 for 1.5 oz.

Plantain Lite: A lighter, everyday plantain chip option


Creating 10 Diverse Personas
We built personas across multiple demographic dimensions: - Gender: Male/Female - Age ranges: 18-25, 26-33, 34-41, 42-50 - Health conditions: Hypertension, obesity, heart disease, asthma, food allergies, digestive issues, or none - Ethnicity: Latino or Not Latino - Location: Urban, suburban, or rural
Examples included: - Young urban health-conscious Latina (18-25, no health conditions) - Middle-aged suburban Latino managing hypertension (42-50) - Young urban non-Latino with food allergies (26-33, gluten/dairy/nuts) - Middle-aged rural non-Latino with obesity (34-41) - Middle-aged rural Latina with multiple conditions (42-50, hypertension + obesity)
The goal was to represent our potential target segments and see how different audiences responded to each product.

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
text:
The Calibrated Survey

Starting with a Benchmark
We calibrated responses by having participants rate Lay‚Äôs Classic Potato Chips first as a reference point. This gave us a common baseline to compare against: - 1 = Unacceptable, wouldn‚Äôt eat even if free - 3 = Acceptable/Average, meets basic expectations - 5 = Excellent, exceeds expectations


Comprehensive Rating Categories
The survey covered:
A. Overall Satisfaction (quality, purchase intent, recommendation likelihood)
B. Taste & Flavor (overall taste, flavor intensity, saltiness, naturalness, aftertaste)
C. Texture & Physical Quality (crunchiness, thickness, consistency, oiliness, freshness)
D. Visual Appeal (appearance, color, uniformity, packaging appeal, information clarity)
E. Value & Competitive Positioning (value for money, price sensitivity, preference vs potato chips and competitors)
F. Product Attributes (uniqueness, healthiness, suitability for guests, meeting expectations)
G. Usage Context (purchase frequency, consumption occasions)
Each persona rated 33 quantitative questions plus provided qualitative feedback on likes, improvements, and how they‚Äôd describe the product.

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
section: What We Learned from the Exercise
text:
What We Learned from the Exercise

AI Can Generate Plausible Responses
ChatGPT was surprisingly good at maintaining consistent personas. The middle-aged rural Latina with hypertension and obesity consistently flagged sodium concerns and price sensitivity across multiple questions. The young urban health-conscious Latina responded positively to premium positioning and cultural connection.
The personas felt internally coherent - their ratings for saltiness, healthiness, and value aligned with their demographic profiles and stated health concerns.


But It‚Äôs Still Simulated Data
The fundamental limitation: these aren‚Äôt real taste preferences. The AI is generating statistically plausible responses based on stereotypical associations between demographics and preferences.
For example, it ‚Äúknows‚Äù that someone with hypertension should care about sodium, so it rates accordingly. But it can‚Äôt actually tell us if our specific salt level tastes good or if the Peruvian sal de Maras provides a noticeably different experience.


Useful for Initial Direction
Where this exercise helped: - Identifying which demographic segments might prefer premium vs everyday positioning - Spotting potential concerns (price sensitivity in rural markets, sodium levels for health-conscious segments) - Practicing survey design before using it with real participants - Understanding how different personas might prioritize different product attributes

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
text:
Serious Limitations

No Actual Sensory Experience
The biggest problem: ChatGPT hasn‚Äôt tasted anything. It can‚Äôt tell us if our plantain chips are actually crunchy, if the salt level is genuinely balanced, or if the flavor profile works.
All taste-related responses are based on generic associations (‚Äúpremium plantain chips should be crunchier,‚Äù ‚Äúsimple seasoning means less salty‚Äù). These might not match reality.


Reinforces Stereotypes
The AI generates responses based on demographic patterns it learned from training data. This means it might reproduce stereotypical assumptions rather than capturing actual individual preferences.
A real 42-year-old Latino with hypertension might not care about sodium as much as the persona suggests, or might have completely different taste preferences than ‚Äútypical‚Äù for that demographic.


Can‚Äôt Capture Real Market Dynamics
Things the simulation can‚Äôt tell us: - Whether people would actually notice our product on shelves - If the packaging design triggers emotional responses - Whether word-of-mouth would happen organically - If there are unexpected use cases we haven‚Äôt considered - How brand perception builds over time


The Validation Problem
We built in validation checks (questions 31-33) to catch inconsistent rating patterns. But when the AI is generating all responses, it‚Äôs just validating its own internal consistency, not actual human behavior.
According to research on AI-generated synthetic data, using LLM outputs as substitutes for human research data can introduce systematic biases that aren‚Äôt immediately obvious.

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
text:
How We‚Äôre Actually Using This

Initial Hypothesis Testing
The AI focus group helped us form hypotheses about product positioning: - Cuzco Crunch might appeal more to urban health-conscious consumers willing to pay premium - Plantain Lite could work better for price-sensitive families and convenience-focused shoppers - Both products might face sodium concerns from health-conscious segments
But these are just hypotheses that need real validation.


Survey Design Practice
Building the comprehensive survey instrument was valuable. We learned: - Which questions provide useful differentiation - How to structure rating scales with proper calibration - What validation checks to include - Which demographic factors might matter most
The survey itself is now ready to use with actual participants.


Next Steps with Real People
We‚Äôre not making product decisions based on AI responses. The plan is: 1. Use the survey with real taste testers 2. Compare actual results to AI predictions 3. Identify where AI assumptions were wrong 4. Make product decisions based on real preferences
The AI exercise was a dress rehearsal, not the actual performance.

title: Running a Virtual Focus Group with ChatGPT
text:
Final Thoughts
Running a virtual focus group with AI personas was an interesting experiment in using LLMs for product development. It‚Äôs useful for: - Rapid hypothesis generation - Testing survey instruments - Exploring how different demographic segments might respond - Practicing market research methodologies
But it‚Äôs dangerous if you: - Trust the responses as actual market data - Skip real human testing because ‚Äúwe already did AI testing‚Äù - Make product decisions based on simulated preferences - Assume the AI understands nuanced taste experiences
For Cuzco Crunch, this exercise helped us structure our research approach and form initial hypotheses. But we‚Äôre clear that actual product validation requires real people tasting real chips. The AI can simulate responses, but it can‚Äôt simulate whether our plantain chips actually taste good.
