title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Artificial intelligence systems like ChatGPT and Claude can engage in conversations, solve problems, and generate content. However, their underlying mechanisms are fundamentally different from human cognition.
These systems operate as sophisticated pattern recognition and prediction engines. While they can produce human-like responses, they function by identifying statistical patterns in data rather than developing conceptual understanding.
 AI neural networks are inspired by brain structure but operate through different mechanisms

Key Question: How do statistical pattern-matching systems produce seemingly intelligent behavior?

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Artificial intelligence systems like ChatGPT and Claude can engage in conversations, solve problems, and generate content. However, their underlying mechanisms are fundamentally different from human cognition.
These systems operate as sophisticated pattern recognition and prediction engines. While they can produce human-like responses, they function by identifying statistical patterns in data rather than developing conceptual understanding.
 AI neural networks are inspired by brain structure but operate through different mechanisms

Key Question: How do statistical pattern-matching systems produce seemingly intelligent behavior?

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Core Architecture: Prediction Systems
Modern AI systems solve a fundamental prediction problem: given an input, determine the most statistically likely output. This applies whether predicting the next word in text, pixels in an image, or moves in a game.

Transformer Architecture
Current large language models like GPT-4 and Claude use transformer architecture:
# Simplified transformer process
def transformer_prediction(input_text):
    tokens = tokenize(input_text)  # Convert text to processable units
    embeddings = convert_to_vectors(tokens)  # Map to numerical representations
    
    for layer in neural_layers:
        embeddings = attention_mechanism(embeddings)  # Identify relationships
        embeddings = feed_forward(embeddings)  # Process patterns
    
    return predict_next_token(embeddings)  # Generate most likely continuation
 Transformer architecture with attention and processing layers
Modern systems operate at significant scale. GPT-3 contains 175 billion parameters trained on 45TB of text data. GPT-4 is estimated to exceed 1 trillion parameters with correspondingly higher computational requirements.


Attention Mechanisms
The attention mechanism enables models to focus selectively on different input elements when making predictions.
Example: ‚ÄúThe cat sat on the mat because it was comfortable.‚Äù
When determining what ‚Äúit‚Äù refers to, the attention mechanism assigns weights: - ‚Äúcat‚Äù (high attention - 0.7) - ‚Äúmat‚Äù (medium attention - 0.2) - ‚Äúsat‚Äù (low attention - 0.1)
This mechanism allows processing of relationships between distant elements in sequences.

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Training Process
AI system development occurs through structured training phases that determine capabilities and limitations.
 Complete pipeline from data collection to deployed system

Phase 1: Pre-training
Systems learn from large text datasets through next-token prediction:

Data Collection: Process text from websites, books, and articles
Tokenization: Convert text to discrete units for processing
Prediction Training: Train models to predict missing tokens in sequences
Parameter Adjustment: Iteratively modify billions of parameters based on prediction accuracy

# Simplified training loop
for epoch in range(many_epochs):
    for text_chunk in massive_dataset:
        input_tokens = text_chunk[:-1]  # Input sequence
        target_token = text_chunk[-1]   # Target prediction
        
        prediction = model(input_tokens)
        loss = calculate_error(prediction, target_token)
        
        # Update model parameters
        model.update_weights(loss.gradient())


Phase 2: Fine-tuning
Pre-trained models are refined for specific applications:

Supervised Fine-tuning: Training on curated question-answer pairs
Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF): Using human preferences to shape responses
Safety Training: Implementing guidelines to avoid harmful outputs

This process transforms basic text predictors into conversational assistants.

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Emergent Capabilities
Large-scale training produces capabilities that weren‚Äôt explicitly programmed. These emergent abilities arise from complex interactions between simple components.

Examples of Emergence
As model size increases, new capabilities develop:
Chain-of-Thought Reasoning: Models develop step-by-step problem-solving approaches without explicit training on this strategy.
In-Context Learning: Systems can perform new tasks based on examples in prompts without additional training.
# Example of in-context learning
prompt = """
Translate English to French:
Hello ‚Üí Bonjour
Goodbye ‚Üí Au revoir
Thank you ‚Üí Merci
Good morning ‚Üí 
"""

# Model produces "Bonjour" despite no explicit
# training on this translation task
Cross-Lingual Transfer: Models trained primarily on English can operate effectively in other languages.
The mechanisms underlying emergence remain an active research area, with theories including phase transitions, increased representational capacity, and pattern recognition thresholds.

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
System Limitations
Current AI systems have several fundamental constraints that stem from their statistical architecture:
 Overview of AI system capabilities and constraints

Pattern Matching vs.¬†Understanding
AI systems process statistical relationships in symbols rather than developing conceptual understanding. They can accurately reproduce information without grasping underlying mechanisms.
Example: A system can state that ‚Äúwater boils at 100¬∞C‚Äù without understanding molecular behavior, phase transitions, or the physical processes involved.


Output Generation Under Uncertainty
Systems are designed to produce responses even when lacking relevant information, leading to plausible but potentially inaccurate outputs.
# Simplified response generation
def generate_response(query):
    if confidence_score > threshold:
        return retrieve_known_information(query)
    else:
        # System still generates output
        return generate_plausible_response(query)


Training Data Constraints
Models are limited by their training data cutoff and cannot incorporate new information without retraining.


Memory Limitations
Current systems can process limited context windows (typically 4,000-128,000 tokens) with no persistent memory between conversations.


Correlation vs.¬†Causation
Systems excel at identifying statistical correlations but have limited understanding of causal relationships. They may recognize that umbrella sales correlate with rain without understanding the causal mechanism.

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Practical Implications
Understanding AI architecture has important implications for effective use:

System Strengths

Pattern recognition and text generation capabilities
Rapid processing of large information sets
Accessible interface for complex tasks
Consistent performance within training domains



Appropriate Applications

Content drafting and editing
Information synthesis from known sources
Code generation and debugging assistance
Language translation
Creative brainstorming



Best Practices

Verify Important Information: Fact-check outputs for critical applications
Understand Limitations: Recognize domain constraints and knowledge cutoffs
Maintain Human Oversight: Keep humans involved in important decisions
Recognize Bias: Be aware that systems reflect training data biases
Use as Tools: Apply systems as analytical instruments rather than authoritative sources

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Future Development
Current AI systems represent early implementations of statistical learning approaches. Several research directions may expand capabilities:

Near-Term Developments (1-3 years)

Multimodal systems integrating text, images, audio, and video
Extended context windows for longer conversations and documents
Improved reasoning and problem-solving capabilities
Specialized models optimized for specific domains



Long-Term Research Areas (10+ years)

Artificial General Intelligence research
Questions about machine consciousness and subjective experience
AI alignment and safety considerations



Active Research Questions
Researchers are investigating fundamental questions:

Scaling Laws: Relationships between model size, data, and capabilities
Emergence Mechanisms: Why new abilities appear at certain scales
Alignment: Ensuring AI systems operate according to intended objectives
Interpretability: Understanding internal model representations and processes

title: How AI Systems Work: A Technical Overview
text:
Summary
Modern AI systems represent sophisticated statistical engines that process patterns in data to generate human-like outputs. While they demonstrate impressive capabilities, they operate through pattern matching rather than conceptual understanding.

Key Technical Points
Current AI systems achieve intelligent-seeming behavior through statistical pattern processing rather than understanding. This approach has several implications:

For Users: Understanding system strengths and limitations enables more effective application
For Organizations: Appropriate use requires human oversight and verification processes
For Society: New frameworks are needed for evaluating machine capabilities and limitations

Statistical pattern matching at scale produces sophisticated behavior, suggesting that aspects of intelligence may be more computational than previously understood.
As these systems become more prevalent, understanding their statistical nature becomes increasingly important for effective implementation. The technology continues evolving rapidly, with ongoing research addressing questions about scaling, emergence, and alignment with human objectives.
The field represents significant progress in automated pattern recognition and generation, with continued development likely to expand capabilities while maintaining the fundamental statistical architecture.

Understanding the technical foundations of AI systems helps inform appropriate use and realistic expectations about current capabilities.

title: Using LLMs for Interview Prep
text:
With consulting recruiting coming up, I built a custom project in Claude to help with case interview prep. The idea was to have a dedicated space where I could practice cases, track my progress, and get feedback‚Äîall in one place.
 Generic stock photo of a professional interview setting

title: Using LLMs for Interview Prep
text:
With consulting recruiting coming up, I built a custom project in Claude to help with case interview prep. The idea was to have a dedicated space where I could practice cases, track my progress, and get feedback‚Äîall in one place.
 Generic stock photo of a professional interview setting

title: Using LLMs for Interview Prep
text:
How the Assistant Works

The Setup
I created a Claude project called ‚ÄúMBB Interview Assistant‚Äù with custom instructions:

‚ÄúYou will be hearing inputs from MBB interviews. Your role as my highly-paid MBB tutor is to come up with frameworks. Answer questions quickly and brainstorm potential questions, and then‚Ä¶ develop a MECE, MBB approach (case structure).‚Äù

The project has become a repository of my case practice‚ÄîI can see all my past cases listed: UK leisure club market analysis, UK media company revenue challenges, Science magazine revenue decline, Residential cable company alarm services, Kids Place Daycare Capacity Strategy.


Using the Voice Recording Feature
The most useful feature has been Claude‚Äôs voice recording capability. I can speak through a case out loud, and it transcribes everything accurately and then provides feedback. This simulates the verbal nature of actual case interviews better than typing.
For example, when I was working through the UK leisure club case, I could talk through my framework structure verbally, and Claude would follow along and point out gaps in my logic or areas I hadn‚Äôt considered.

title: Using LLMs for Interview Prep
text:
What Actually Works

Case Tracking
Having all my practice cases in one place is genuinely helpful. I can see which types of cases I‚Äôve worked on and which I need more practice with. The project view shows each case with timestamps, so I can track my prep progress over time.


Framework Development
Claude is good at helping me structure MECE (Mutually Exclusive, Collectively Exhaustive) frameworks. When I‚Äôm stuck on how to break down a problem, it can suggest logical buckets to organize my thinking.
For the daycare capacity strategy case, it helped me think through supply-side factors (staffing, facilities, regulations) and demand-side factors (demographics, competition, pricing) in a structured way.


Accurate Transcription
The voice recording feature transcribes my verbal case practice accurately. I can review what I actually said rather than what I thought I said, which helps identify verbal tics or unclear explanations.


Quick Feedback
It provides immediate feedback on structural issues‚Äîmissing elements in my framework, calculations I didn‚Äôt account for, or assumptions I should have stated explicitly.
 My MBB Interview Assistant project showing case history and files

title: Using LLMs for Interview Prep
text:
Major Limitations I‚Äôve Found

Hallucinations and Made-Up Information
This is the biggest problem. Claude sometimes makes up data points or industry facts that sound plausible but aren‚Äôt real. In the media company revenue case, it cited specific market statistics that I later couldn‚Äôt verify anywhere.
For interview prep, this is dangerous because you might memorize false information and confidently state it in a real interview. I‚Äôve learned to verify anything that sounds like a specific fact or statistic.


Going Off Topic
Sometimes Claude diverges from the specific case question to discuss tangentially related concepts. When working on the cable company alarm services case, it started explaining general IoT trends instead of focusing on the specific competitive positioning question I was asking about.


Scope Creep
The AI occasionally suggests frameworks or analyses that are way too broad for a 20-minute case interview. It might recommend conducting customer surveys or building complex financial models‚Äîthings that wouldn‚Äôt be feasible in an actual interview setting.


Weird or Broken Links
When Claude tries to reference sources or suggest additional reading, the links are often fabricated or don‚Äôt lead anywhere useful. I‚Äôve clicked on several suggested resources only to find they don‚Äôt exist.


Can‚Äôt Simulate Real Pressure
The fundamental limitation remains: practicing with an AI in my room doesn‚Äôt replicate the pressure of a real interviewer. There‚Äôs no one judging my confidence, no awkward silences to manage, no reading of facial expressions.
Research on case interview preparation emphasizes that the interpersonal dynamics and time pressure are critical elements that can only be practiced with real people.

title: Using LLMs for Interview Prep
text:
My Actual Approach

Early-Stage Framework Practice
I use the Claude project at the beginning of my prep for each case type. It helps me understand what a good framework looks like and gives me immediate feedback on structural issues.


Verbal Practice Tool
The voice recording feature is useful for getting comfortable speaking through cases out loud. I can practice articulating my thinking without the pressure of another person listening.


Progress Tracking
The project acts as a log of all the cases I‚Äôve practiced. I can see patterns in which types of cases I struggle with and where I need more work.


Always Verify Facts
I never trust specific data points or statistics from Claude without verification. If it mentions a market size or industry trend, I look it up independently.


Real Humans Are Essential
After using Claude for initial structure practice, I do the same cases with actual people‚Äîfriends doing consulting recruiting, career services, or case partners. The AI gets me to baseline competence faster, but real practice is what actually prepares you for the interview dynamic.

title: Using LLMs for Interview Prep
text:
Final Take
The MBB Interview Assistant project is a useful supplementary tool but comes with significant limitations. It‚Äôs good for: - Organizing and tracking case practice - Getting quick structural feedback - Practicing verbal articulation with voice recordings - Understanding framework basics
But it‚Äôs actively harmful if you: - Trust its specific facts without verification - Rely on it as your primary practice method - Follow its suggestions when they‚Äôre too broad or impractical - Think it can replace practicing with real people
The hallucination issue is serious enough that I treat everything Claude says as a suggestion to verify rather than information to memorize. For actual interview prep, the AI is a starting point, not a replacement for traditional practice methods.

title: Building a Brand with AI: Cuzco Crunch
text:
Eury and I decided to try building a snack brand called Cuzco Crunch, mostly to see how much of the process we could handle using AI tools. We are just experimenting with what‚Äôs possible when you use GPT for everything from naming to packaging concepts.
 Initial logo concepts generated through AI prompting

title: Building a Brand with AI: Cuzco Crunch
text:
Eury and I decided to try building a snack brand called Cuzco Crunch, mostly to see how much of the process we could handle using AI tools. We are just experimenting with what‚Äôs possible when you use GPT for everything from naming to packaging concepts.
 Initial logo concepts generated through AI prompting

title: Building a Brand with AI: Cuzco Crunch
text:
What We‚Äôre Using AI For

Brand Development
The name ‚ÄúCuzco Crunch‚Äù came from asking GPT to suggest names that sounded distinctive but not too weird. We wanted something that hinted at South American flavors without being too on-the-nose. It generated about 30 options and this one felt right.


Packaging Design Direction
We‚Äôre using AI to create mood boards and design concepts. Instead of hiring a designer upfront, we‚Äôre generating different packaging styles to see what resonates. The AI helps us think through color schemes, typography, and overall brand personality.


Marketing Copy
Product descriptions, social media posts, and even this blog post started with AI-generated drafts that we then edited. It‚Äôs faster than staring at a blank page, and sometimes the AI suggests angles we wouldn‚Äôt have thought of.
 Various packaging design concepts and color schemes

title: Building a Brand with AI: Cuzco Crunch
text:
What‚Äôs Working and What Isn‚Äôt

The Good Stuff
Speed is the biggest advantage. We can iterate on ideas quickly without waiting for external feedback or spending money on design consultations. The AI is also good at generating variations - give it one concept and it‚Äôll produce 10 different takes on it.


The Limitations
Everything needs human editing. The AI-generated copy often sounds too generic or tries too hard to be clever. Design concepts look decent but lack the subtle details that make professional packaging stand out on shelves.
Also, the AI doesn‚Äôt understand practical constraints. It‚Äôll suggest elaborate packaging designs that would be expensive to produce or flavors that might not actually taste good together.
 3D mockups and shelf visualization concepts

title: Building a Brand with AI: Cuzco Crunch
text:
The Reality Check

Still Need Real Skills
AI handles the brainstorming and initial concepts, but you still need to understand branding, know your target market, and make business decisions. It‚Äôs a tool, not a replacement for actual knowledge about building a brand.


Cost vs.¬†Quality Trade-offs
We‚Äôre probably saving money in the early stages, but there‚Äôs a point where you need professional designers and marketers. The question is finding that sweet spot where AI gets you far enough to make informed decisions about what‚Äôs worth investing in.


Learning Experience
The most valuable part has been understanding how much work goes into brand development. Using AI to handle the repetitive parts lets us focus on strategy and decision-making instead of getting stuck on execution details.
We‚Äôre treating this as an experiment rather than a serious business venture. If Cuzco Crunch turns into something real, great. If not, we‚Äôve learned a lot about using AI for creative projects and brand development.

title: Research with Perplexity AI
text:
I‚Äôve been trying out Perplexity AI for research tasks lately. It‚Äôs different from regular Google searches because it synthesizes information from multiple sources and gives you one coherent answer with citations.
 Perplexity AI interface showing search results with sources

title: Research with Perplexity AI
text:
I‚Äôve been trying out Perplexity AI for research tasks lately. It‚Äôs different from regular Google searches because it synthesizes information from multiple sources and gives you one coherent answer with citations.
 Perplexity AI interface showing search results with sources

title: Research with Perplexity AI
text:
How It Works

Getting Information from Multiple Sources
Instead of opening multiple tabs and reading through different articles, Perplexity pulls information from various sources and combines it into a single response. When I was researching market trends for a work project, I got a summary that included key points from several industry reports, all with proper citations.


Follow-up Questions
You can ask follow-up questions that build on your previous search. After asking about ‚Äúsustainable packaging trends 2025,‚Äù I could continue with: - ‚ÄúWhat are the cost implications?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhich companies are leading this transition?‚Äù - ‚ÄúHow does this compare to 2024 predictions?‚Äù
The AI remembers the context, so you don‚Äôt need to re-explain what you‚Äôre looking for.
 Live citations and source integration in action

title: Research with Perplexity AI
text:
When It‚Äôs Useful

Academic Work
Good for getting an overview of research topics and finding relevant studies. Helps identify what‚Äôs already been studied and where there might be gaps.


Business Research
Useful for market analysis and industry trends. You can ask specific questions and get answers that draw from recent reports and news sources.


Learning New Topics
When you‚Äôre unfamiliar with a subject, it can explain concepts and provide background without having to piece together information from multiple websites.


Fact-Checking
Since it shows sources for each piece of information, it‚Äôs easier to verify claims and see where data comes from.

title: Research with Perplexity AI
text:
What I‚Äôve Found

Saves Time
The main benefit is speed. You get the key information faster since it‚Äôs already compiled from multiple sources. You still need to read the original sources for details, but the initial overview is much quicker.


Clear Sources
Every piece of information comes with citations, so you can see exactly where it came from and verify it if needed.


Handles Context Well
The conversation aspect works better than I expected. You can refine questions or explore related topics without starting over.


Shows Different Viewpoints
When sources disagree, it usually mentions the different perspectives rather than just presenting one view.
It‚Äôs a useful tool for the initial stages of research when you need to understand a topic quickly or gather information from multiple sources. Not a replacement for thorough research, but it does help speed up the information gathering process.

title: AI Photo Organization: Finding Pictures I Forgot I Had
text:
I realized I had over 10,000 photos in Google Photos and no way to find specific ones. Today I tried using the AI search features to locate pictures from last year‚Äôs vacation, and it actually worked better than expected.
 Google Photos AI recognizing objects, people, and locations

title: AI Photo Organization: Finding Pictures I Forgot I Had
text:
I realized I had over 10,000 photos in Google Photos and no way to find specific ones. Today I tried using the AI search features to locate pictures from last year‚Äôs vacation, and it actually worked better than expected.
 Google Photos AI recognizing objects, people, and locations

title: AI Photo Organization: Finding Pictures I Forgot I Had
text:
What the AI Can Find

Object Recognition
I searched for ‚Äúpizza‚Äù and it found every photo with pizza in it, even ones where pizza was just sitting on a table in the background. Same thing worked for ‚Äúdog,‚Äù ‚Äúbeach,‚Äù and ‚Äúbirthday cake.‚Äù The AI recognizes way more objects than I expected.


Face Grouping
Google Photos automatically groups photos by faces, so I can find all pictures of specific people without having to manually tag them. It even recognizes people as they age or in different lighting.


Location and Time
If you have location data turned on, you can search by place names. I found all my photos from ‚ÄúSan Francisco‚Äù or ‚Äúcoffee shop‚Äù pretty easily. Time-based searches work too - ‚Äúphotos from summer 2024‚Äù pulled up the right time period.
 Automatically created albums based on events and trips

title: AI Photo Organization: Finding Pictures I Forgot I Had
text:
Automatic Albums

Trip Detection
The AI creates albums for trips automatically based on location and date patterns. It figured out my weekend in Portland and grouped all those photos together without me doing anything.


Event Recognition
It also makes albums for things like ‚ÄúBirthday party‚Äù or ‚ÄúGraduation‚Äù based on the types of photos and timing. Sometimes it gets it wrong - labeled a regular dinner as a ‚Äúcelebration‚Äù - but it‚Äôs right more often than not.


People Albums
Creates collections of photos featuring specific people, which is useful for family pictures or when you want to share photos of someone with them.

title: AI Photo Organization: Finding Pictures I Forgot I Had
text:
Limitations

Privacy Concerns
All this convenience requires uploading your photos to Google‚Äôs servers where they analyze everything. If that bothers you, you can‚Äôt really use these features.


Sometimes Too Smart
The AI occasionally creates albums for things that weren‚Äôt actually events, or groups random photos together based on superficial similarities.


Search Isn‚Äôt Perfect
Complex searches don‚Äôt always work. ‚ÄúPhotos of John at the beach‚Äù might miss some or include wrong results. Simple, single-concept searches work much better.
It‚Äôs genuinely useful for finding old photos you‚Äôd never locate otherwise. The search functionality makes having thousands of photos actually manageable instead of just overwhelming.

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
text:
I‚Äôm taking Human Disease and Evolution this semester, and it‚Äôs incredibly note-intensive. Every lecture covers evolutionary biology, epidemiology, pathogen adaptation, and historical case studies‚Äîall dense material that builds on previous content. By midterms, I had hundreds of pages of notes with no clear way to study them efficiently.
I decided to test whether Claude could help synthesize these notes and work as a study partner. Not just summarizing, but actually helping me understand connections and prepare for exams.

Dense notes from Human Disease and Evolution lectures

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
text:
I‚Äôm taking Human Disease and Evolution this semester, and it‚Äôs incredibly note-intensive. Every lecture covers evolutionary biology, epidemiology, pathogen adaptation, and historical case studies‚Äîall dense material that builds on previous content. By midterms, I had hundreds of pages of notes with no clear way to study them efficiently.
I decided to test whether Claude could help synthesize these notes and work as a study partner. Not just summarizing, but actually helping me understand connections and prepare for exams.

Dense notes from Human Disease and Evolution lectures

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
text:
How I‚Äôm Using Claude

Initial Upload and Organization
I created a Claude project specifically for the course and uploaded: - Lecture notes from the first 8 weeks - Reading summaries - Professor‚Äôs study guide questions - Previous exam questions (from the syllabus)
Then I asked:

‚ÄúI‚Äôve uploaded notes from my Human Disease and Evolution course. Help me organize the main themes across lectures and identify connections between topics.‚Äù

Claude produced a thematic breakdown: - Evolutionary pressures on pathogens - Host-pathogen coevolution - Historical transitions (hunter-gatherer ‚Üí agricultural ‚Üí urban) and disease emergence - Trade-offs in immune response - Case studies (malaria, tuberculosis, influenza)
This was immediately useful. My notes were chronologically organized by lecture, but the exam tests conceptual understanding across topics.


Synthesizing Across Lectures
My next prompt:

‚ÄúWe covered malaria in weeks 2, 4, and 7 from different angles. Synthesize all the malaria content into one coherent explanation covering: evolutionary biology, geographic distribution, historical impact, and current challenges.‚Äù

Claude pulled information from multiple lecture sets and created a unified overview. This saved me from manually cross-referencing my notes across different weeks.


Generating Practice Questions
For active recall practice:

‚ÄúBased on the uploaded notes, generate 10 exam-style questions that test conceptual understanding, not just memorization. Include questions that require applying concepts to new scenarios.‚Äù

The questions were decent: - ‚ÄúHow would you expect pathogen virulence to evolve in a population with high vs.¬†low host density?‚Äù - ‚ÄúExplain why tuberculosis resurged in urban populations during industrialization using evolutionary principles.‚Äù
These forced me to think beyond memorizing facts.

Evolutionary dynamics between hosts and pathogens

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
text:
What Actually Helped

Finding Connections I Missed
Claude identified patterns across lectures that I hadn‚Äôt noticed while taking notes in real-time. For example, the concept of ‚Äúvirulence-transmission trade-offs‚Äù appeared in multiple contexts (influenza, cholera, malaria), but I‚Äôd written it down separately each time without seeing the unifying principle.


Clarifying Confusing Concepts
When I asked:

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt fully understand the relationship between R0 (basic reproduction number) and herd immunity threshold. Explain using the influenza example from my notes.‚Äù

Claude broke it down using the specific examples from my lectures, not generic textbook explanations. This was more helpful than Googling because it referenced the actual case studies we‚Äôd covered.


Creating Study Guides
Instead of re-reading hundreds of pages, I asked:

‚ÄúCreate a two-page study guide covering the five most important concepts from weeks 1-8, with specific examples from the notes.‚Äù

The condensed version helped me review quickly before office hours and identify gaps in my understanding.

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
text:
Significant Limitations

Can‚Äôt Replace Actually Studying
The biggest misconception would be thinking Claude can study for you. It can‚Äôt.
When I tried asking Claude to quiz me on material, I noticed I could ‚Äúcheat‚Äù by asking for hints or looking back at its previous responses. The lack of real accountability meant I wasn‚Äôt forcing myself to actually retrieve information from memory.
According to research on active learning, the cognitive struggle of retrieval is what builds long-term retention. AI tools that make information too easy to access can undermine this.


Factual Accuracy Issues
Claude occasionally made small errors when synthesizing across notes: - Mixing up dates for historical disease outbreaks - Slightly mischaracterizing which regions certain diseases are endemic to - Conflating similar but distinct evolutionary concepts
These weren‚Äôt obvious hallucinations‚Äîthey were plausible-sounding errors that I only caught because I‚Äôd attended the lectures. If I‚Äôd been using Claude to learn new material rather than organize existing notes, I might not have noticed.


Can‚Äôt Capture Lecture Nuance
My professor emphasizes certain concepts or says ‚Äúthis will be on the exam.‚Äù Those verbal cues don‚Äôt make it into my typed notes, so Claude can‚Äôt prioritize what‚Äôs actually important vs.¬†what‚Äôs just background information.
It treats all information in my notes equally, when some concepts are more central than others.


Dependence Risk
There‚Äôs a real risk of becoming dependent on AI for synthesis and losing the ability to do it myself. The mental work of organizing information and finding connections is part of learning‚Äîoffloading that entirely to AI might make me better at using AI but worse at actual thinking.
Research on cognitive offloading to technology suggests that over-reliance on external tools can reduce our own cognitive abilities over time.

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
section: Is Claude Actually a Good Study Partner?
text:
Is Claude Actually a Good Study Partner?

What Makes a Good Study Partner
Real study partners: - Challenge your understanding by asking probing questions - Notice when you‚Äôre bullshitting and call you out - Have their own understanding that you can compare against - Hold you accountable for actually studying
Claude does some of this (asking questions, providing alternative explanations) but fails at others (accountability, challenging weak understanding).


Where It Actually Works
Claude is better described as a ‚Äúnote organization assistant‚Äù than a ‚Äústudy partner.‚Äù It‚Äôs useful for: - Synthesizing large amounts of text quickly - Finding patterns across multiple documents - Generating initial practice questions - Creating structured study guides
These are valuable, but they‚Äôre the preliminary work before actual studying begins.


The Accountability Gap
The biggest difference between Claude and a human study partner: I can‚Äôt fool Claude, but I also can‚Äôt fool myself into thinking Claude-assisted studying counts as real studying.
When I study with friends, the social pressure and explanation requirement force actual learning. With Claude, I can go through the motions of ‚Äústudying‚Äù while not really engaging deeply with the material.

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
text:
How I‚Äôm Actually Using It

Early-Stage Organization Only
I use Claude at the beginning of my study process: 1. Upload notes after several lectures 2. Get thematic organization and connections 3. Create initial study guide 4. Generate practice questions
Then I study using traditional methods: spaced repetition flashcards, practice problems without AI help, and study groups with actual humans.


Verification Against Lecture Materials
Anything Claude synthesizes, I verify against: - Original lecture slides - Textbook readings - Professor‚Äôs posted materials
I don‚Äôt trust Claude‚Äôs synthesis as the final word‚Äîit‚Äôs a starting point that I refine.


Using It for Weak Areas
When I identify concepts I don‚Äôt understand well, I ask Claude for additional explanations or examples. But then I test my understanding by explaining it to a friend without AI help.


Real Study Sessions Stay Human
My actual exam prep involves: - Study groups with classmates - Office hours with TA and professor - Practice exams under time pressure - Teaching concepts to others
Claude handles the logistical grunt work of organizing notes, but learning happens through human interaction and cognitive struggle.

title: Using Claude to Synthesize Dense Class Notes
text:
Final Assessment
Using Claude to synthesize dense class notes is genuinely useful for note-intensive courses. It saves time on organization and helps identify connections across material.
But calling it a ‚Äústudy partner‚Äù overstates what it can do. It‚Äôs more like a smart organizational tool that can handle the tedious work of cross-referencing and initial synthesis.
The real learning‚Äîdeep understanding, retention, application‚Äîstill requires traditional study methods and human interaction. Claude can make the prep work more efficient, but it can‚Äôt replace the cognitive work of actually studying.
For Human Disease and Evolution specifically, Claude helped me organize a semester‚Äôs worth of dense notes into a manageable study plan. But I‚Äôm not bringing Claude into the exam room‚ÄîI need to make sure the knowledge is in my head, not just in my AI assistant‚Äôs context window.
The tool is helpful. But over-relying on it would be a mistake that probably shows up when exam day arrives.

title: AI Do‚Äôs and Don‚Äôts: Safe and Effective Usage
text:
AI tools are powerful but require careful usage. These guidelines help you maximize benefits while avoiding common pitfalls.
 Key principles for responsible AI usage

title: AI Do‚Äôs and Don‚Äôts: Safe and Effective Usage
text:
AI tools are powerful but require careful usage. These guidelines help you maximize benefits while avoiding common pitfalls.
 Key principles for responsible AI usage

title: AI Do‚Äôs and Don‚Äôts: Safe and Effective Usage
text:
What TO Do

‚úÖ Verify Important Information
Always fact-check AI outputs for: - Medical or health advice - Financial decisions - Legal matters - Technical specifications - Current events or recent data
Cross-reference with authoritative sources before acting on AI recommendations.


‚úÖ Be Specific in Your Prompts
Instead of: ‚ÄúHelp me with my presentation‚Äù Use: ‚ÄúCreate an outline for a 10-minute sales presentation to executives about Q3 revenue growth‚Äù
Specific prompts produce more useful results.


‚úÖ Use AI for Brainstorming and Drafts
AI excels at: - Generating initial ideas - Creating first drafts - Organizing thoughts - Providing alternative perspectives
Use AI output as a starting point, not a final product.
 Proper workflow: AI assists, human validates and refines


‚úÖ Maintain Human Judgment
Keep human oversight for: - Final decision-making - Quality assessment - Ethical considerations - Context that AI might miss


‚úÖ Ask Follow-Up Questions
Improve results by asking: - ‚ÄúCan you explain this differently?‚Äù - ‚ÄúWhat are potential problems with this approach?‚Äù - ‚ÄúGive me three alternatives‚Äù - ‚ÄúMake this more specific‚Äù

title: AI Do‚Äôs and Don‚Äôts: Safe and Effective Usage
text:
What NOT to Do

‚ùå Don‚Äôt Share Sensitive Information
Never input: - Passwords or login credentials - Social Security numbers - Credit card details - Proprietary business information - Personal addresses or phone numbers - Private family details
Assume all AI conversations could be stored or accessed by others.


‚ùå Don‚Äôt Rely on AI for Critical Decisions
Avoid using AI alone for: - Medical diagnoses or treatment - Legal advice or document preparation - Financial investment decisions - Safety-critical calculations - Emergency situations
Consult qualified professionals for these matters.
 Areas where AI should not be the primary decision maker


‚ùå Don‚Äôt Assume AI is Always Accurate
AI can produce: - Outdated information - Factual errors - Biased responses - Plausible-sounding but incorrect details
Especially problematic for recent events or specialized technical information.


‚ùå Don‚Äôt Use AI for Harmful Purposes
Avoid requesting: - Misleading or false content - Harassment or threatening messages - Plagiarism or academic dishonesty - Illegal activity guidance - Discriminatory content


‚ùå Don‚Äôt Ignore Context Limitations
AI doesn‚Äôt understand: - Your full personal situation - Unspoken cultural context - Real-time environmental factors - Emotional nuances
Provide necessary context explicitly in your prompts.

title: AI Do‚Äôs and Don‚Äôts: Safe and Effective Usage
text:
Implementation Strategy

Start Small
Begin with low-stakes tasks like email drafting or meal planning before using AI for important projects.


Build Verification Habits
Develop a routine of checking AI outputs against reliable sources.


Keep Learning
AI capabilities and limitations evolve. Stay informed about updates and new research.


Document What Works
Save effective prompts and note which applications produce reliable results for your needs.
 Use these tips and tricks!
Following these guidelines ensures you gain AI‚Äôs benefits while avoiding common mistakes that can lead to poor decisions or security issues.

title: AI Fitness Coaching at Home
text:
I tried the Freeletics app today instead of going to the gym. It uses your phone‚Äôs camera to watch your form and give feedback in real time, which felt like having a trainer watching you.
 Smartphone analyzing exercise form with real-time feedback

title: AI Fitness Coaching at Home
text:
I tried the Freeletics app today instead of going to the gym. It uses your phone‚Äôs camera to watch your form and give feedback in real time, which felt like having a trainer watching you.
 Smartphone analyzing exercise form with real-time feedback

title: AI Fitness Coaching at Home
text:
How It Works

Real-Time Form Correction
You prop your phone up and the camera tracks your movements. When I was doing squats, it noticed I wasn‚Äôt going low enough and told me to ‚Äúsquat deeper‚Äù right as I was doing the exercise. It also caught that I was leaning too far forward.


Counts Reps Automatically
The app counts your repetitions so you don‚Äôt have to keep track. It only counts reps with proper form, so if your push-up doesn‚Äôt go low enough, it won‚Äôt count it.


Adjusts Based on Performance
When I started struggling with burpees halfway through, the app suggested switching to a modified version. It seemed to pick up on the fact that my form was getting sloppy and offered an easier variation.

title: AI Fitness Coaching at Home
text:
What Works Well

Form Feedback
The corrections are actually helpful. It‚Äôs like having someone watch you who knows what proper form looks like. Caught several things I didn‚Äôt realize I was doing wrong.


No Equipment Needed
All bodyweight exercises, so you can do it anywhere. The app designs workouts based on what space and time you have available.


Adapts to Your Level
Starts with easier exercises and gradually increases difficulty based on how you perform. If you‚Äôre struggling, it scales back. If you‚Äôre crushing it, it adds more challenging moves.


Tracks Progress Over Time
Keeps track of how many reps you can do and how your form improves. You can see whether you‚Äôre getting stronger or if certain exercises are still difficult.

title: AI Fitness Coaching at Home
text:
Limitations

Camera Angle Matters
You need to position your phone correctly for it to see your whole body. Took a few tries to get the angle right.


Lighting Requirements
Works better in good lighting. Had trouble tracking movements when the room was too dim.


Limited Exercise Types
Focuses mainly on bodyweight movements. If you want to lift weights or use equipment, you‚Äôll need a different approach.


Not Always Perfect
Sometimes misses form issues or gives feedback that doesn‚Äôt quite match what you‚Äôre doing. Still better than working out with no guidance, but not as precise as a human trainer.
It‚Äôs a solid option for home workouts when you want some structure and feedback. The form correction feature is genuinely useful, especially for exercises you‚Äôre not familiar with.
